title: Broke
description: The Michael Scott Paper Company is gaining clients by offering lower prices than Dunder Mifflin, but is going broke in the process. However, Dunder Mifflin is losing clients to Michael, and is desperate to buy him out.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: It's 4:30 in the morning.  Do you know where your kids are?  If you are Ryan's parents or Pam's parents or my parents, you do.  They're gonna be in this van.  With me.  Who am I?  Nothing to fear.  I am just a 44 year old guy with a paper route.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [honking horn] Time to make the donuts. [laughs and drives away as Ryan tries to get in the van]  Come on.  Whoa! No, I promise I won't do it again.  Come on.  [does it again] De-nied!

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: We've been making 5:00 AM deliveries for a couple weeks now.  Ever since I've gotten clean there's something about fresh morning air that... just really makes me sick.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hello! Time to make the donuts!  Oh, Halpert! Whoa! Boner patrol. Arrest that man! Your donuts make me go nuts!  [laughs] Hey Pam.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: We got the van at a used car lot.  We think it says "Alleluia Church of Scranton." in Korean.  It was either this or an old school bus with an owl living in it.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: You didn't happen to bring any coffee, did you, Michael?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Milk and sugar.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Oh, awesome.  You're a life saver.  [drinks from coffee cup] Wait, is this just milk and sugar?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That's what I said.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Do you drink this every day?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Every morning.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We're, uh, we're doing okay.  A couple weeks in and, um, we're having fun.  Uh, yep.  We have 20- of those.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: [an Asian lady tries to enter the van] Oh, oh, excuse me!  Sorry. Sorry, no.  It's, uh, it's a paper company now.  It's not for the church.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Okay, who covers Bans Pet Grooming?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, they're my client.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: No, they were your client.  They just called and told us they're switching over to Michael Scott Paper Company.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [sighs] Shame, Jim.  I expected more.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: In the last month we have lost ten major clients to Michael Scott.

quotes.speaker: Stanley
quotes.text: What are we supposed to do?  They keep undercutting us on price.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: I don't want to hear excuses.  I want to see improvements.  This is unacceptable.

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: Hey, Boss. Uh, I'd just like to point out that I have been here less time than these guys.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Why are you telling me this?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I just think the bar should be lower for a newbie.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Is this something you really want to have said?

quotes.speaker: Andy
quotes.text: I don't want to have said that.  But I think it's important that you know it.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: I don't know what to do to inspire these people. Okay, maybe it's my fault-

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: It's not your fault. Some people just don't want to be inspired.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: I wrote a memo to all departments asking them to find ways to save money but, uh-

quotes.speaker: Angela
quotes.text: Charles, I got your memo. Thank you. I want you to know I'm putting my foot down when it comes to expense reports.  Waste not, want not.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Uh, well said, Angela.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Been there, done that.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: You know what we need?  We need some couches in here.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Michael, we should really consider getting a delivery guy.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Oh, you know what you would love? Is if we built a loft.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Why would I love that? Can we afford a delivery guy?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Like in a dorm room.  You put your desk underneath, you have your loft up top.  You can sleep up top.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Yeah, I know what a loft is.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Most dorm rooms don't even have that.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Most do in the magazines.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Let's see what a delivery guy costs.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We should look into that.  Or we just go for the loft.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Would you let Charles know that David is here, please?  Jim, hey.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Hey, David.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: David Wallace! Hello, we've been expecting you, David Wallace.  Charles and I were waiting for you.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: There he is. There he is.  How was the trip up?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: A lot better than a month at the Scranton Radisson, I'm sure.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Oh, you know it hasn't been that bad.  Hasn't been that bad.  These people are the salt of the earth down here.  You couldn't ask for a better way to learn a company.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Hmmm.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: I feel like I should be thanking you.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Uh.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: [makes kissing, puckering sound]

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: The conference room is ready if we want to get started.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: You know, I just want to address everyone first.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Oh yeah, take your time.  Stanley, pay attention.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Hi, everyone.

quotes.speaker: Kelly
quotes.text: Hi.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Hi.  Uh, look it's no secret-

quotes.speaker: Kevin
quotes.text: Hi.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Hello.  Uh, it is no secret that Michael Scott Paper has siphoned off a large chunk of our core business.  And I'm here- I just want to assure everyone that we think this is just a temporary setback.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Right.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay?

quotes.speaker: Phyllis
quotes.text: Maybe, and I don't know, if you had just returned Michael's call none of us would've lost clients.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: I've been wondering that myself lately.  We're just gonna get started, we're gonna figure this out. Rest assured.  Jim, can you come in with us please?

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Uh, Jim hold on. [whispers] You know, David, uh, Dwight's been my guy.  Okay?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Hmm.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Yeah, Jim-

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: I find that extraordinarily surprising.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: He shows promise and Jim, I don't know- I- he's been a disappointment.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: We'll bring them both in.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Okay, great.  Uh, Dwight come on in.  Also, Jim.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Come along, afterthought.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: How much can we afford to pay a delivery guy?

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Well, if these numbers you gave me are correct-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: They are correct, sir.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Then you can't afford to pay him anything.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay. A lame attempt at humor.  Swing and a miss.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Your prices are too low.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Lowest in town.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Why do you think Staples and Dunder Mifflin can't match your prices?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Corporate greed?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Look, our price model is fine. I reviewed the numbers myself.  Over time with enough volume, we become profitable.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Yeah, with a fixed cost pricing model that's correct.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: But you need to use a variable cost pricing model.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, sure. Right, so- why don't you explain what that is to- so that they can under- just explain what that is.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Explain what you think that is.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: Okay.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Explain that.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: As you sell more paper and your company grows, so will your costs. For example, delivery man, health care...

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Well, we don't-

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: ...business expansion-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Whatever, yeah.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: At these prices, the more paper you sell, the less money you'll make.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Our prices are the only thing keeping us in business.

quotes.speaker: Financial Guy
quotes.text: They're actually putting you out of business.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, okay.  Hold on, hold on.  Ty, I would like you to crunch those numbers again.

quotes.speaker: Ty
quotes.text: It's a program.  There's no such thing-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Just crunch 'em.  Just crunch 'em please.

quotes.speaker: Ty
quotes.text: [presses key on computer] Crunch.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Did it help?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hi, Jerry.  Michael Scott.  Well, this is slightly embarrassing. [laughs] Um, I'm going to have to... ask you to pay me a little bit more money for that delivery we dropped off yesterday.  Yeah. We did. We got the check, but we're just going to need a much, much bigger check.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: When a child gets behind the wheel of a car and runs into a tree, You don't blame the child.  He didn't know any better.  You blame the 30-year-old woman who got in the passenger seat and said, "Drive, kid.  I trust you."

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Now, would corporate approve a temporary price reduction for returning customers?

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: God, no.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Stupid.  Yeah, makes us look weak.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: I agree.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I say we fill Michael's office with bees.  My apiarist owes me a favor.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Really? Does he do good work or-

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [scoffs] No, Jim. I use a bad apiarist. [sighs]

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Fellas, why don't we take a five-minute break and then we will come back, start fresh, sort this out.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Five minutes exactly.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Okay.  Hey, Dwight.  Can I talk to you?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Sure thing.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: [opens phone] Hey. I saw you called.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You're just out of business?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: We have maybe a month.  I don't know what I'm gonna do.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, yeah, well don't worry about it.  We'll figure it out.  We'll be okay.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: That's what Michael said.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, yeah. Only this time we will be okay.  [cell phone rings; Dwight's voice saying "Idiot, Idiot, Idiot"] Oh, that's my new "Dwight" ring.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: I like it.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Good, right?  Hello.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: [over phone] Idiot, we're starting back up.  This is Dwight, by the way.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, okay. [kisses Pam] Don't worry about it.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Did I ever tell you about the day that Steve Martin died?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Steve Martin's not dead, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I know.  But I always thought that the day that he died would be the worst day of my life.  I was wrong.  It's this.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: You want to hear something sad?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I would love that.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: So Jim and I are getting married and the wedding's really expensive.  So I tried to get a job on the weekends to earn extra money.  I applied to Old Navy, Target and Wal-mart.  None of 'em called me back.  Not even for an interview.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: I never went to Thailand.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Really?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: I went to Fort Lauderdale.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Was it nice?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Yeah, it was amazing.  There was a great Pad Thai place, though.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I love Pad Thai.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: You've never had Pad Thai.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No.  There's a lot I haven't done.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Now, this is the projection over three months?

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: We still have the inventory sitting- [everyone starts chattering at once]

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Let me float something out there, okay?  Can I just say- can I say something?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Yeah, yeah.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: There is a hive of bees outside the front door.  We kidnap the queen, extract her alarm pheromones, place them on a flushable wipe, put that in his bathroom.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: I can't believe I'm about to say this, but the cheapest option... is to make Michael an offer.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Yes.  Yes, I was gonna say the same thing.  We should buy him out.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, but you didn't.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Oh, Man!  If only Michael had children.  That's how you really apply the pressure.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: What is wrong with you?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Jim, you're- you're pretty close with him.  You think they'd be up for hearing an offer?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh, I don't know. You know, they've taken a good deal of clients, so-

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: I mean I guess- I guess I could go down there and try to nudge them in the right direction.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You know what?  Why don't I do it, okay? Michael adores me.  I'm the man for this job.  Charles, you got my back on this?

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: No, Jim... I think you should go.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Okay, so I'll be back in, um- back in a bit.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [knocking on door] Hmm?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Hey, can I talk to you guys for a second?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We're not hiring, Jim.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Actually here for something else.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Listen, I can't make you laugh right now.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: You know I love a good guessing game, but why don't I just tell you what I'm here for?  Turns out you guys have made a pretty big dent in the Dunder Mifflin sales.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Oh, that's nice.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: David Wallace has asked me to come down here and see if you would be interested in Dunder Mifflin buying you out.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Seriously?  Are you being serious?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: He's bluffing, Pam.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Jim, what you don't understand is that this company's worthl-

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No- We don't have-

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Oh!  See I'm here to learn as little information as possible.  All I really need to hear is if your incredibly successful company would be receptive to a buyout.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [stammers] Uh... Yes.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Yes.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Maybe.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Three yeses.  I will see you titans of industry upstairs.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yes, well, we're not only tight-ends, we are also quarterbacks.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Missed the last part.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That's a pun.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Got it.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yep. Oh... wow.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Okay, so you are not going to reveal  in any way that we're broke.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Of course not.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: That we're having any problem at all.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Nope, nope, nope.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Just to reiterate, none of us is going to say anything that might indicate that we are going broke.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Right, right. There is no way in hell that I am going to say that we're broke.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Oh, I'm really worried that I'm going to say it.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: No, Michael.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Ah...

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: No, man.  You're- you're fine.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: We have to come from a position of strength.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I'm good, I'm good.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Just put it out of your mind.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: It is.  I'm good.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Hello.

quotes.speaker: Erin
quotes.text: Hi.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Michael Scott Paper Company to see Mr. David Wallace.  I believe we're expected.  [David and Charles walk out of conference room] Well, well, well. How the turntables...

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Michael, in order to expedite these negotiations, we are prepared to make you a very generous offer.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And we are prepared to reject that offer.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Michael, you  haven't even heard-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Never accept their first offer.  What is your second offer?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Are you kidding me?  That is insultingly low.  I don't even want to hear what your first offer was.

quotes.speaker: Angela
quotes.text: What do you hear?

quotes.speaker: Kelly
quotes.text: [mumbles]

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Here's the situation.  Your company is four weeks old.  I know this business.  I know what suppliers are charging.  I know you can't be making very much money.  I don't know how your prices are so low, but I know it can't keep up that way.  I'm sure you're scared.  Probably in debt. This is the best offer you're gonna get.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I'll see your situation and I'll raise you a situation.  Your company is losing clients left and right.  You have a stockholder meeting coming up and you're going to have to explain to them why your most profitable branch is bleeding.  So they may be looking for a little change in the CFO.  So I don't think I need to wait out Dunder Mifflin.  I think I just have to wait out you.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay, now I don't know that I can get this. I do have to go to the board for approval. How's about $60,000.  Hmm?  $60,0000.  Michael?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: [stutters] We'll have to talk-

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: What?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: We'll have to talk about this.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Mm-hmm.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Just amongst ourselves.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay, yes. Please take the room. Be right outside.  Take your time.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Oh, my God. Oh, my God.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: We are so rich.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Are you kidding me?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Well, Jerry, the one who got away.  May I ask why you're leaving the Michael Scott Paper Company?  Really?  Please hold.  [gets up and runs to kitchen]  Charles.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Dwight.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: May I have your attention?  The Michael Scott Paper Company is broke.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: What?  How'd you hear that?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: They've been calling all of their clients and begging them to pay more money.  That can only mean one thing.  They're desperate.  Which can only mean one thing.  They're total failures.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Great work Dwight.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Quiet you.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: No, I mean, great detective work.  'Cause this must be the first case you've ever cracked, right?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: You don't crack a case.  That has pejorative connotation.  That's like calling a policeman a cop.  You solve a case, and yes, I've solved plenty.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: So how long can they stay viable?

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: What are your top five cases?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I'm gonna answer Charles first.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Because you've solved zero cases.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Okay, one. Case of the beet bandit.  Missing beets from all over the farm.  No footprints. Inside job.  Mose in socks.  Boom, case closed.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Okay, do  not go anywhere near the conference room.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Done.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Because you have embarrassed me for the last time today.  Got it?

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: I'm not- I'm not following you.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: You two are morons.

quotes.speaker: Jim
quotes.text: Got it.

quotes.speaker: Dwight
quotes.text: Wh-

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Get out.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: So you've thought it over, yes, and you accept our offer.  We can finally put this whole thing behind us?  Hmm?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Can you give us another minute please?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Yeah.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Oh, okay.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Michael.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: How could you do this to me, Michael?  You just cost me $60,000.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Why are you assuming you'd get the whole thing?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: It's a lot of money, okay.  But we need money coming in every week.  We need jobs.  Wouldn't you rather have a fishing pole than a fish?

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: I would rather have $60,000, honestly.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: No, Michael's right.  Jobs are safer.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Agreed?

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Agreed.  But that's all, okay.

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Yeah, discuss these things-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Shut up, shut up.  Hello?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I want my old job back.  I want my old parking space back.  I want a Sebring.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: They don't make them anymore.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And I want Charles gone.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: I am not firing Charles.  He is very valuable.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: That's very kind of you to say, David.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: I need him gone.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: No.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Okay, then I want Pam back.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Uh, you already have a new receptionist-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Sales.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Thank you.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Pam's not a salesperson.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yes, she is.  At the Michael Scott Paper Company in it's heyday.

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: That's right.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay.  Please continue.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And Ryan.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Ryan cost Dunder Mifflin hundreds of thousands of dollars, Michael.  Ryan is-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: You know, David.  I don't care if Ryan murdered his entire family he is like a son to me.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Do you realize what you're asking for here?  You're talking about salary plus health benefits-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: And dental this time.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Insurance, taxes, social security for three people.  This is a heck of a lot more than 60 grand.  You're talking about a multi-million dollar buy-out.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: These are our demands.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Your company cannot be worth that much.

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Our company is worth nothing.  That's the difference between you and I.  Business isn't about money to me, David.  If tomorrow my company goes under, I will just start another paper company.  And  then another and another and another.  I have no shortage of company names.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Michael-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: That's one of 'em! Yes.  These are our demands.  This is what we want.  Our balls are in your court.

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Okay.  Deal.  Okay?

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Can we have the room please?

quotes.speaker: David Wallace
quotes.text: Yeah. [David and Charles leave room, Michael shuts the door and closes the blinds]

quotes.speaker: Ryan
quotes.text: Yes, yes, yes!

quotes.speaker: Pam
quotes.text: Alright!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: Yes! Can you believe it?  That's what I'm talking about!

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: There are certain defining moments in a person's life.  The day he is born.  The day he grows hair.  The day he starts a business. And the day he sells that business back to Dunder Mifflin.  What have I learned from all of this?  It is far too early to tell.  I just know that I am flying high and I don't even want to think about it.  I just want to enjoy it.

quotes.speaker: Charles
quotes.text: Hey, guys-

quotes.speaker: Michael
quotes.text: No, no. You're done.
